Adhikarana_1.name: जिज्ञासाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_1.विषयः - Topic: ब्रह्मजिज्ञासा - The inquiry into Brahman and its necessity
Adhikarana_1.संशयः - Samshaya: Is inquiry into Brahman necessary? Can liberation be attained through karma alone?
Adhikarana_1.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Karma (ritualistic actions) alone is sufficient for liberation. There is no need for knowledge of Brahman.
Adhikarana_1.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: Knowledge of Brahman is essential for liberation. Karma prepares the mind but cannot directly lead to moksha. Therefore, inquiry into Brahman (brahma-jijnasa) is necessary after acquiring the four-fold qualifications.
Adhikarana_1.notes: This is the foundational adhikarana establishing the purpose of Vedanta study. The word 'atha' indicates auspicious beginning.

Adhikarana_2.name: जन्माधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_2.विषयः - Topic: जन्माद्यस्य यतः - The origin, sustenance, and dissolution of the universe and Brahman as the ultimate cause
Adhikarana_2.संशयः - Samshaya: What is 'janmadyasya yatah'? Does it refer to Pradhana (primordial matter) or Brahman?
Adhikarana_2.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Pradhana (Prakriti), the inert primordial matter of Sankhya philosophy, is the cause of the universe.
Adhikarana_2.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: Brahman alone is both material and efficient cause. Only omniscient Brahman, not inert Pradhana, can create because creation requires knowledge and deliberation (ikshati).
Adhikarana_2.notes: This is the lakshana (definition) sutra of Brahman. Establishes Brahman as both intelligent and material cause.

Adhikarana_3.name: शास्त्रयोनित्वाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_3.विषयः - Topic: शास्त्रयोनित्वम् - The scriptures as the source of knowledge about Brahman
Adhikarana_3.संशयः - Samshaya: Can Brahman be known through perception, inference, or other means? Or are scriptures the only source?
Adhikarana_3.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Brahman can be known through inference and reasoning, similar to knowing the existence of atoms.
Adhikarana_3.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: The Vedas (shabda pramana) are the only valid means of knowing Brahman. Brahman is beyond perception and inference as it transcends the sensory and intellectual realm.
Adhikarana_3.notes: Establishes that scriptural testimony is indispensable for knowledge of Brahman, though reasoning can support scriptural teachings.

Adhikarana_4.name: समन्वयाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_4.विषयः - Topic: समन्वय - The harmony and consistency of all Upanishadic texts in teaching Brahman
Adhikarana_4.संशयः - Samshaya: Do all Upanishads teach about Brahman consistently, or do they have different meanings?
Adhikarana_4.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Upanishadic texts have diverse teachings and cannot be harmonized to teach one subject.
Adhikarana_4.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: All Upanishads harmoniously (samanvaya) teach about Brahman alone. Apparent differences are reconcilable through proper interpretation.
Adhikarana_4.notes: Establishes the unity and consistency of Vedantic teaching across all Upanishads regarding Brahman.
Adhikarana_4.references: Chandogya, Brihadaranyaka, and other major Upanishads

Adhikarana_5.name: ईक्षत्यधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_5.विषयः - Topic: ईक्षति - The 'seeing' or deliberation of Brahman before creation as mentioned in Chandogya Upanishad
Adhikarana_5.संशयः - Samshaya: Does 'It saw' (aikshata) refer to Brahman or Pradhana? Can an inert entity deliberate before creation?
Adhikarana_5.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Pradhana, being the material cause, can be the subject of 'seeing' through figurative language.
Adhikarana_5.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: Only Brahman, being conscious, can deliberate (ikshati). The word 'seeing' indicates conscious deliberation, which is impossible for inert Pradhana. The Creator must be intelligent.
Adhikarana_5.notes: This adhikarana establishes Brahman as both intelligent and the cause of creation through the argument of conscious deliberation.

Adhikarana_6.name: आनन्दमयाधिकरणम्
Adhikarana_6.विषयः - Topic: आनन्दमय - Whether the Anandamaya (bliss-sheath) mentioned in Taittiriya Upanishad refers to Brahman or merely to a modification
Adhikarana_6.संशयः - Samshaya: Does 'anandamaya' refer to Brahman or to the bliss-sheath (anandamaya kosha), which is just a modification of the mind?
Adhikarana_6.पूर्वपक्षः - Purvapaksha: Anandamaya is just the causal body (karana sharira) or innermost sheath, not Brahman itself. The suffix 'mayat' indicates modification, not the essence.
Adhikarana_6.सिध्दन्तः - Siddhanta: Anandamaya is Brahman because the Upanishad describes it with characteristics of Brahman: it is the tail/support (puccha) of other sheaths, it is described as sat-tyam (reality), and the context indicates Brahman. The suffix 'mayat' here means 'abundant in' (bliss), not 'modification of'.
Adhikarana_6.notes: This adhikarana establishes that the innermost reality is Brahman itself, not merely a covering. The five sheaths (koshas) culminate in Brahman as their substratum.
